- [x] Add `liminf_add_ge_gt₂`
- [x] Add `liminf_add_top_ne_bot`
- [x] Add `add_liminf_le_liminf_add`
- [x] Add `limsup_le_iff`
- [x] Add `limsup_le_const_forall`
- [x] Add `const_le_limsup_forall`
- [x] Add `liminf_le_const_forall`
- [x] Add `const_le_liminf_forall`
- [x] Add `limsup_max`

Co-authored-by: @D-Thomine 

---

- [x] depends on: #14125

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ ge_iff_le_forall_real_lt`
`+ liminf_add_gt_of_gt`
`+ liminf_add_top_of_ne_bot`
`+ liminf_le_liminf`
`+ liminf_neg`
`+ limsup_add_bot_of_ne_top`

</details>
Thank you very much @j-loreaux for your comments. I'll certainly do that in my future PRs.

This PR/issue depends on:
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#14125~~
By **[Dependent Issues](https://github.com/z0al/dependent-issues)** (🤖). Happy coding!
<!-- By Dependent Issues (Action) - DO NOT REMOVE -->

Thank you @j-loreaux for your review! 

We should have addressed all your comments and suggestions.

Thank you @sgouezel for your review! 

I have replied negatively to your question and committed your suggestion.

We should have addressed all the comments and suggestions. 

Thank you @j-loreaux and @sgouezel for your review!

:v: pitmonticone can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).
bors r+

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9793648084/job/27042001738)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9793648084/job/27042002433)

Could you also move a and b to the `variables` line and remove them from the statements?
bors d+
Thanks!

Could you also move a and b to the `variables` line and remove them from the statements?
bors d+
Thanks!

Let me explain the vast changes I'm suggesting here:
1. you can just use refine and swap the arguments of `⟨⟩` instead of using `symm`.
2. when using refine, you can introduce `?_` wherever, like in `fun h ↦ ?_`, and then you don't have to `intro` so many things
3. the `induction` syntax allows you to name the cases, which can be helpful, especially when you would like to name variables like `x y` in the second `h_real` case.
4. you can just inline your `specialize` bits where you use them.
5. `exact_mod_cast` can do `norm_cast` while supplying the term
6. when you use `by_contra!`, it uses `push_neg` on the introduced hypothesis.
```suggestion
  refine ⟨fun h ↦ ?_, fun h z x_lt_z ↦ le_trans h (le_of_lt x_lt_z)⟩
  induction x using EReal.rec
  case h_bot =>
    refine ((eq_bot_iff_forall_lt y).2 fun z ↦ ?_).le
    apply lt_of_le_of_lt <| h (z - 1) (bot_lt_coe (z - 1))
    exact_mod_cast sub_one_lt z
  case h_real =>
    induction y using EReal.rec
    case h_bot => exact bot_le
    case h_real x y =>
      norm_cast at h ⊢
      by_contra! x_lt_y
      rcases exists_between x_lt_y with ⟨z, x_lt_z, z_lt_y⟩
      exact not_le_of_lt z_lt_y <| h z x_lt_z
    case h_top =>
      exfalso
      exact not_le_of_lt (coe_lt_top (_ + 1)) <| h (_ + 1) (EReal.coe_lt_coe_iff.2 (lt_add_one _))
  case h_top => exact le_top
```
That's amazing! Thank you very much for the explainer!

You should be able to get this? Or is it false because of `EReal`?
```suggestion
    (ha : limsup u f < a) (hb : limsup v f < b) : limsup (u + v) f < a + b := by
```

Yes, thanks. 

We didn't manage to prove it directly, but we used `limsup_add_le_of_le` to prove the more general `limsup_add_lt_of_lt`.
Is your statement true if you weaken `hb` to a large inequality?

No, weakening either `hb` or `ha` results in the statement being false.

With the weakened hypothesis `hb`, only the following statement can be proved:

```lean
limsup (u + v) f ≤ a + b
```
Well, that's the current conclusion of the lemma, right? My question is whether, weakening hb, you can still have the conclusion `limsup (u + v) f ≤ a + b`.

Oh, I see. You were talking about `limsup_add_le_of_le`. 

Yes, in that case I can weaken `hb` leaving the statement true.
I apologize, but GitHub comments are frequently displayed alongside incorrect lines.
Done. Thanks.
Unless I missed something, you haven't answered this one.

Sorry, I have just realised I hadn't submitted the comments (were pending as review comments instead of standard ones).

We have just finished answering this one as follows: 
- [x] Add `add_le_add_right`, `add_le_add_left` and `add_le_add` in Data/Real/EReal.lean
- [x] Use `add_le_add_right ` to prove `limsup_add_le_of_le`
Can you not employ some sort of `wlog` argument here? (Maybe even a manual one using `suffices` instead of the actual `wlog`)
Honestly, I am not sure how to do it in this case.

There should be a short proof of this that uses [EReal.negOrderIso](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Data/Real/EReal.html#EReal.negOrderIso) and the above version for `limsup`, although you may need to prove a lemma of the form `limsup (-v) = - liminf v` or something to that effect, but this should follow easily from the above order isomorphism.
```suggestion
lemma liminf_add_ge_gt₂ {α : Type _} {f : Filter α} {u v : α → EReal} {a b : EReal}
    (ha : a < liminf u f) (hb : b < liminf v f) : a + b < liminf (u + v) f := by
```

@j-loreaux: That was my first idea, but the problem is that negation does not commute with addition on EReals (i.e. `-(x + y)` is not the same thing as `(-x) + (-y)`), because of the edge case `⊥ + ⊤ = ⊥`. I didn't see any clever idea around it.

Hi @D-Thomine. Notice that this comment is outdated. Please take. A look at the “Files Changed” section. 

@LorenzoLuccioli and I have already addressed this issue.
Again, just dualize with [EReal.negOrderIso](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Data/Real/EReal.html#EReal.negOrderIso)
I think I can do it but probably the proof wouldn't be shorter than the current one because we need to handle `-(u + v) = -u + -v` manually since it's not always true in the `EReal`s.
ditto
You can dualize again to get a `liminf_min` version
Done. Thanks.

```suggestion
  induction x
```

```suggestion
    rw [hb']
```
Ops. Done, thanks.
Instead of registering a specific lemma for EReal, can you instead register the right typeclass so that the general lemma `add_le_add_right` applies? Same thing for the other lemmas below.

We have just removed our EReal-specialised implementation of `add_le_add_right` and `add_le_add_left` since we have noticed that the more general `_root_. add_le_add_right` and `_root_. add_le_add_left` worked perfectly well. 

We were just applying them incorrectly...
This lemma is a little bit strange, because it is completely superseded by other lemmas below. Can you add a docstring to the lemma, with pointers to the better statements?

@sgouezel: Even `limsup_add_bot_ne_top` is superseded by `limsup_add_le_add_limsup` (although deriving the former from the latter is slightly cumbersome), so `limsup_add_le_add_limsup` is really the main result we care about.

It was, however, more comfortable to write three lemmas instead of a giant proof of one lemma.

What would be the best option? I can see a few possibilities :

- Keeping the file this way.
- Add docstrings pointing toward the right statements
- Folding the two obsolete lemmas into the proof of the third.
- Marking `limsup_add_le_of_lt` (and maybe `limsup_add_bot_ne_top`) as private.

By the way, since `limsup_add_le_of_lt` is superseded in the end, I don't think it is valuable to try to optimize its hypotheses or conclusion -- cf. yesterday's thread with you and @j-loreaux.
Marking the lemmas as private *and* adding docstrings explaining by which statements they are superseded would probably be the best option.

Ok, I have just added the following docstring: 

```lean
/-- This lemma is superseded by `limsup_add_le_of_le` (weaker hypothesis) and
`limsup_add_lt_of_lt` (stronger thesis). -/
lemma limsup_add_le_of_lt {α : Type*} {f : Filter α} {u v : α → EReal} {a b : EReal}
    (ha : limsup u f < a) (hb : limsup v f < b) : limsup (u + v) f ≤ a + b := by
```
Note that my message is saying to mark the lemmas as private *and* add docstrings.
Yes, I know. I was isolating the docstring to refer to it in this conversation.
Now I have pushed the private status and the other docstring.
All the theorems in your PR should be lemmas. The rule (not yet enforced) is that `theorem` is only for important statements, and in particular all theorems should have a docstring.
This one should also be removed, `_root_.add_le_add` works just fine.
Done, thanks.
In all this section, you have `{α : Type*} {f : Filter α} {u v : α → EReal}`. Make these section variables ?
Sure.
Done, thanks.
It's not really superseded as the conclusion is a little bit different. I agree it's easy to deduce this one from the other one, but still I wouldn't mark it as private because it could be handy.
Ok, done. Thanks.

```suggestion
lemma limsup_le_const_of_forall_le {α : Type*} {f : Filter α} {u : α → EReal} {b : EReal}
```
But this lemma doesn't look specific to EReal. In fact, we have a better general version, as limsup_le_of_le. Do you really need the specialized version? Same thing for the next 3 lemmas.

@D-Thomine and I are working on it right now. We have decided to remove these lemmas from this PR and proceed as follows in a new PR: 
* Get the more general version of `limsup_le_of_le`
* `limsup_max`: get a version for conditionally complete linear orders (+ autoparam)
* Then write a version for complete linear orders without the autoparam conditions (for the 4 lemmas),
to be put in `Mathlib.Order.LimsupLiminf`

Is that specific to EReal, or is it true in a general complete linear order? If so, it would be better to have the general version. (Even better, in a general conditionally complete linear order, with suitable boundedness assumptions that are filled by autoparams, just as is done in the file on limsups and liminfs).

@D-Thomine and I are working on it right now. We have decided to remove these lemmas from this PR and proceed as follows in a new PR: 
* Get the more general version of `limsup_le_of_le`
* `limsup_max`: get a version for conditionally complete linear orders (+ autoparam)
* Then write a version for complete linear orders without the autoparam conditions (for the 4 lemmas),
to be put in `Mathlib.Order.LimsupLiminf`

```suggestion
lemma limsup_add_bot_of_ne_top
```

```suggestion
lemma limsup_add_le_add_limsup
```

```suggestion
lemma liminf_neg : liminf (- v) f = - limsup v f :=
```

```suggestion
lemma limsup_neg : limsup (- v) f = - liminf v f :=
```

```suggestion
lemma liminf_add_top_of_ne_bot
```

```suggestion
lemma limsup_le_iff {b : EReal} :
```

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion (h : limsup u f ≠ ⊥ ∨ limsup v f ≠ ⊤) (h' : limsup u f ≠ ⊤ ∨ limsup v f ≠ ⊥) : ```
